article.headline: Kansas State 80, Baylor 69
article.story: MANHATTAN, Kan. (AP) -- Just four days after blowing a 16-point lead in a loss to Oklahoma, Kansas State appeared on the verge of another second-half collapse. But Clent Stewart knocked down his only 3-point attempt to end Baylor's comeback bid, and after squandering an 18-point lead, the Wildcats hung on for an 80-69 win Wednesday night. "I was getting a couple of flashbacks," Lance Harris said. "I was just telling everybody to knock down free throws and we'll be all right." Jeremiah Massey led the Wildcats with 24 points, but it was Stewart's 3-pointer after Baylor closed within 60-58 with 4:42 to go that gave Kansas State some breathing room. "He's not a very good 3-point shooter," Wildcats coach Jim Wooldridge said, "but he was able to get it down. He's not afraid to take that shot." Kansas State (14-10, 4-9 Big 12) then made 13-of-14 free throws in the waning minutes to pull away. Patrick Fields scored a career-high 22 points for Baylor, which lost its 10th in a row. Tim Bush added 18 points but had six turnovers. "We played with a lot of resiliency," said Wooldridge, whose team snapped its own six-game losing streak. "We dug ourselves a hole tonight and we had some tough times to get through." But it was Baylor (9-15, 1-12) that dug the hole early in the second half, going nearly five minutes without a field goal. Kansas State went on a 14-1 run and built a 50-32 lead with 15:56 to go. "K-State came out with a great deal of energy and sense of urgency," Baylor coach Scott Drew said. The Wildcats then got sloppy, allowing the Bears to slowly creep back. Freshman Aaron Bruce, who had 20 points for Baylor, knocked down a jump shot and followed it up with a 3-pointer to get within 57-49 with under 10 minutes to go. By the time Bruce curled in another jump shot with six minutes to go, Baylor had closed to 59-56. "We got a little careless at times," Wooldridge said. "We gave Baylor some life and confidence to keep going." But unlike Saturday, when Oklahoma's Drew Lavender hit the game-winner with no time left to complete the comeback, Kansas State didn't give Baylor a chance. It stuck in the back of my mind for a while," Harris said of the 69-68 loss. "But that's what is good about the Big 12. You get to come back out and play another game." Cartier Martin scored 15 points, Harris had 14 and Fred Peete added 10 points and eight assists for Kansas State. Baylor played without forward Tommy Swanson, who missed the game with an eye injury. Kansas State took advantage of the resulting mismatches, continually pounding the ball inside. The Wildcats outrebounded Baylor 35-19 and had a 46-22 advantage in points in the paint. "They did a great job of getting the ball inside," Drew said. "We did not have a scholarship player over 6-foot-6, and that hurt us inside tonight."

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
